payload.name: temporal
payload.core: Reason about ordering, duration, persistence, and change over time. Model when events occur, how long states persist, and what triggers transitions between states.

out.form: ordered sequence of states and transitions
out.test: all events placed with no contradictions

out.form: list of what holds until changed
out.test: each assumption has explicit invalidation trigger

out.form: state transitions with timestamps and causes
out.test: every change has identified trigger event

proc: identify temporal entities: events, states, intervals, instants
declare persistence: state what holds by default until changed
model transitions: specify triggers that invalidate persistence
check consistency: verify no circular or contradictory orderings
check: all events have relative or absolute time placement
persistence assumptions are explicit not implicit
transition triggers are specified for each state change
timeline accounts for all known events

diff.modal: modal reasons about possibility/necessity; temporal reasons about when truth holds
diff.planning-policy: planning uses temporal to sequence actions; temporal provides the time logic
diff.historical-investigative: historical reconstructs past timelines; temporal provides formal framework

fail.mode: hidden persistence assumptions; assuming things stay true without explicit justification
fail.signal: conclusions rely on unstated 'still true' assumptions; no invalidation conditions
mit: require invalidation triggers for each persistent state
validate timeline consistency before drawing conclusions
distinguish between 'known to hold' vs 'assumed to hold'

ex.ctx: Events: A(login 9:00), B(file-access 9:15), C(logout 9:10). Query: could B have occurred?
ex.analysis: Temporal constraint: A before C (9:00 < 9:10). B at 9:15 is after C. Persistence: session active from A until C. B requires active session. B at 9:15 violates constraint (after logout). Conclusion: B impossible given timeline.
